posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.sub: redpill me on the outlander sport
posts.com:
I think I got a pretty good deal on a lot leftover but new 2022 ES base Outlander Sport. It's only FWD but I live in a very hot fucking state so ice isn't an issue, nor rust.

I'm putting down 9k and got an ok 5% APR for 60 months. Car note is $285 a month, total interest paid will be $2800. This will be my first new ride. My Pop had an old Montero that was a beast and my brother had a 1994 Plymouth Laser/Mitsubishi Eclipse that he drove for years, so we've had good luck with the Tri-Diamond MFG before. I'm not worried about reliability. I know about CVT maintenance. I was dilligent about it with my old Sentra and had about 180k miles on it before I had total engine failure, but no issues with the CVT.

Anyone on here own one of these? Thoughts or opinions appreciated. I know this isn't the most cutting edge CUV out there but it's price point is very within my budget and I like the exterior.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: It's a budget CUV that's completely mediocre in all aspects except for the one thing you didn't opt for, Mitsubishi's excellent AWC. I understand these have been unchanged since 2011 besides aesthetics, so reliablity should be above average. I understand the engine also was in the Lancer as well. In this market though that price is competitive. Did you get a total price on paper? With the feds raising the interests rates, five percent isn't outrageous but still meh. With that said, nothing beats a new car with a warranty just for the excitement factor. I'd guess you'll probably be able to get 150k to 200k miles out of the Outlander Sport or RVR where I'm from.

>It’s true that warming up gas-powered vehicles before driving in cold weather can cause damage to the engine, according to Firestone Complete Auto Care and Smart Motors Toyota, a dealership based in Madison, Wisconsin.

>“If you're one of the many drivers who thinks it's important to turn on your car and let it sit for a bit before hitting the road in wintry weather, you could be doing your engine more harm than good,” Firestone says.

>In a blog post on its website, Smart Motors Toyota says letting your car idle in cold temperatures can shorten the life of your engine by stripping away oil from the engine’s pistons and cylinders — two critical components that help your engine run, Stephen Ciatti, Ph.D., principal engineer for battery systems at PACCAR, told Business Insider in 2016.

>“Less oil means more friction, more wear and tear, and a shorter life for your engine,” Firestone says.

>While some people let their cars idle to warm up the interior, others may actually be trying to protect their engine because of outdated guidance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Firestone and Smart Motors Toyota both say that most cars made before 1980 did need to “warm up” when it was cold out. This is because older model cars had carburetors that regulated the air-fuel mixture within the engine and could not accurately adjust the air-to-fuel ratio in cold weather.

>“In cold temperatures, carburetors couldn't vaporize all the gasoline they let into the engine, so some of it would be left behind as a liquid rather than being burned off during combustion. In order to work properly, a carburetor needed to warm up or else you'd run the risk of stalling out,” Firestone says.

>But times have changed since the 1980s. Nowadays, practically every car sold in the United States has an electric fuel injection system that helps maintain the perfect air-fuel mixture needed for a combustion event, no matter the ambient temperature, according to Firestone and Smart Motors Toyota.

>Instead of waiting for your car to warm up in the winter, most manufacturers recommend driving off gently after about 30 seconds because the engine warms up faster when the car is being driven, according to the U.S. Department of Energy.

>“This means that your cold-day-driving routine should look something like this: bundle up, start the car, scrape the ice off the windows and mirrors, get in the car and get going!” Firestone says.

>Just make sure you don’t accelerate too fast or rev your engine too much in the first few moments you start driving in the cold.

>“This can add unwanted strain to your bearings and flood the combustion chamber with gas, which, in turn, will take miles off your engine’s life,” Smart Motors Toyota says.

Most of the rules of thumb for cars are outdated and given to us by our dads. Fact is most newer engines running any decent oil can probably go a year or 10K without an oil change and be fine. What people really should do is check their oil regularly to inspect the level and color. More often as the engine gets older. I've made a habit of doing it every time I'm at the pump since my engines old and sprung some fast leeks before. Also gives me a good idea of how much life the oil has left in it. Noticed it starts going bad every 4K or so. The same can be said about starting up. In most reasonable climates with modern oils, as long as you're taking it easy until it's fully warmed up you likely aren't causing major issues. It's more important to listen to your engine for a few seconds and scrape off the wind shield.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26187183
It's a reliable car, but you can't neglect maintenance like a Toyota and expect it to be good to you. Take care of the car, and it will take care of you. Most common issues I've seen are crankcase vent failure and the upper electronic module failing. A failed crankcase vent will cause excessive oil consumption and if ignored for long enough will cause the cam seals to rupture and leak oil onto the timing belt. If you don't want to bend all 20 of your valves, replace your crankcase vent as soon as you know it has failed. Common signs of failure are bad oil consumption (check your dipstick regularly between oil changes), oil cap and dipstick are hard to remove during engine idle at operating temperature, or if the rubber hose connected to the charge pipe is covered in oil. The plastic pipe over the valve cover, and the hose connects at the bottom by the radiator fan. I typically only see upper electronic module (UEM) failure on old pieces of shit that come in with SRS lights. Worn shocks and leaking CV axle boots are common too, but that's because the cars are just old.

There's currently a recall out for the steering wheel airbag because it doesn't deploy exactly how Volvo wants it to. If the airbag is dark grey and the plastic cover feels fairly new, safe to say the recall has been performed.

If you're a DIYer, be aware that parts aren't exactly cheap, and if they are they most likely suck. Stick to OEM, or if you're looking for aftermarket upgrades IPD is the way to go. If you take your car to shops, find a Volvo specialist or just take your car to a Volvo dealer. It will be more expensive obviously, but most mechanics are scared to work on Volvos for some reason. Take your car somewhere that's familiar with Volvos and you'll most likely recieve very reliable work

t. Volvo dealer technician, mentor has 43 years of Volvo experience

>FWD = MOAR rear camber
Based brainlet.
The more load you're putting through a tyre the more camber you want, FWDs are generally set up to keep the load more towards the front, rear wheel drives are generally set up to put more load on the rear. Look at the wheel placement for a typical FWD car vs a typical rear wheel drive car if you don't believe me.
Or just look at the back of a rear wheel drive car - look at a GT86 or Mustang, look at a rear biased car like a 911 if you want to see REAL rear camber.

What type of wheel do you have on your SUV, and if it's stock what SUV do you have, model and year?

225/50/17 isn't too far off from 225/55/17 like some anons mentioned. It should work just fine. Run flats are garbage, just buy yourself a VIAIR tire inflation kit off Amazon, nothing too fancy, and get a tire repair kit and watch some videos on Youtube on how to use them. Far more cost effective and you don't have to deal with the unpleasant cancer that is run-flat garbage.

For mostly urban/highway driving like you mentioned but occassional off road use with snow and mountains, I'd highly recommend Michelin Defender LTX M/S tires in 225/55/17. Whenever Costco has a sale for $150 off Michelins which occurs virtually every other month, you can go to a Discount Tire/America's Tire Center and have them price match for you or go to Costco if you have a membership. Higher price up front, however they have a 70k mile warranty and they wear like iron and they outperform other A/T tires in virtually every category except maybe hardcore rock crawling, and even then I've personally used them in that scenario as well and never once trailed behind dudes running KO2s or KM3s. Just don't go mudding with them. They are some of the best selling A/T tires for a reason, and don't get more love because they look like boring grandpa tires compared to KO2s and Wildpeaks, but will absolutely spank them in snowy and icy conditions and in highway driving.

>>26189367
hmmmm what are the advantages of 0w40 vs 5w40? both in summer and winter? how about in older cars?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26189375
first number is just the winter weight, so its viscosity when cold. 0w would be thinner than 5w. the second number is the operating temp viscosity. both are identical when at operating temp.
some older cars may need thicker oil due to seals wearing out or wear and tear resulting in bigger tolerances etc. but it also depends. if the engine was recently rebuilt for example just treat it like a new(ish) engine. I've got a 30 year old engine in mine and used 10w30 and during cold cranking the oil pressure light stayed on noticeably longer than with 5w30, and this is in an area that doesn't see subzero temps.
lower winter weight is better to a certain extent; you don't want it so low that the oil just shears and ends up not actually protecting the engine. Usually the vehicle's owner manual has a chart recommending what to use for what temp ranges.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26187938
>Sure, but -25c impacts an EV's range a lot more than it does the traditional ICE
Only because EVs have so little stored energy, and its not really that EVs are impacted more, it just feels like they're impacted more because fast chargers are rare.
In an ICE car you'll hardly notice an increase of 350Wh/mi due to the cold because you have at least 400kWh of stored energy, and there's gas stations in every small town. You don't even think about doing 20mpg on a trip instead of 25 because the only impact is you maybe make an extra stop for gas, or put a little bit more in.
With an EV an increase just up to 350Wh/mi in the cold can feel massive, because you have 100kWh or less, and fast chargers are 150 miles apart or more in many areas. So if that trip that normally takes you 40kWh suddenly takes over 50kWh you really notice it.

When batteries in typical 4 mile a kWh (3 mile a kWh in the cold) EVs get up to 120 or 130kWh and there's fast chargers every ~50 miles or so, cold weather won't be as much of issue for EVs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26188195
My old VW shitbox.
35mpg most of the year (950 Wh/mi)
20mpg in winter (1700 Wh/mi)
~28mpg annual average (1200 Wh/mi).

VS my current EV daily.
150 mpge most of the year (225 Wh/mi)
110 mpge in winter (310 Wh/mi)
~135 mpge annual average (250 Wh/mi)

>Combustion cars still drive much further
Because they have a lot more stored energy. Most gas cars drive around with 12 to 15 US gallons of fuel, which translates to 400 to 500 kWh.
EVs may be 4-5 times more efficient, but they have a lot less stored energy. 50 to 100 kWh is still common for 'long range' BEVs.

Cars with batteries larger than 100kWh at 200 Wh/kg have really only just started to hit the market, once they become common in more affordable BEVs then ICE's stored energy advantage will be gone. Put a 200 Wh/kg pack in my EV in place of the current 170 Wh/kg pack and it will easily do 300 miles even in the cold.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26155512
International is the cheap fleet truck, they’re shitty. Everything is plastic and the smell of the plastic offgassing is so bad that you need to park with the windows open the first year of the truck’s life

Freightliner is probably #2 from the bottom. They’re solid company trucks, better than International, but nothing special. They might give you one piece of fake wood trim across the dash.

Kenworth is like Peterbilt Jr, the company doesn’t mind spending a couple extra bucks to have good lookin trucks on the road. Our Kenworths are way more comfy than Internationals of the same era.

Peterbilt is like Kenworth but even more of the Murrican Trucker. Tons of gauges with chrome rings around them, for owner-ops and companies that want to have lots of chrome on the road.

Western Star is a more rare one, all custom built trucks, like Peterbilt but more exclusive for the real super truckers.

Volvo is like if Freightliner cared about drivers. I love driving Volvos, lots of extra little touches, like Peterbilt but with a modern Yuro touch. Not sure if servicing them is so easy though.

Mack is a real small market share these days, not sure what happened to them. I saw like zero new Macks between 2000 and maybe 2015. They’re about on par with Kenworth, some chrome and not the cheapest looking, but they’re like 1% or less of trucks on the road so probably not great if you need service in the middle of the country.

posts.com: How do you guys center stickers? Like if I want to center one on my rear windshield, any tricks/tips?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164256
Use a piece of cord*. upper left corner to lower right corner. Mark the approximate center with a liquid chalk pen or something else thats easily removable.
Repeat between upper right corner to lower left corner. X now marks the exact center of your windshield.
*Cord because modern windshields aren't flat surfaces. Cord follows the form.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
After that you measure height and width of your sticker. Divide both values by 2 and you got the center of your stigger too
For example:
Sticker width is 10 inches then 5 inches is the center.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26164262
Alternatively you can use masking tape instead of cord. Either way: Don't get distracted by the fact you won't see a straight line. That's due to the mentioned curvature of the windshield.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I read the FAQ, but what exactly goes into making stickers hardware-wise? I imagine its a gigantic initial investment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26186876
You need a plotter to cut the vinyl and other sticker films. Then you need a printer that's able to print on these materials.
These two devices are the most expensive stuff. And you need a computer with Photoshop or some other top-tier program (inkluding a way to turn regular graphics into plottable graphics) plus a screen that's worth its salt.
Hobby-tier plotters start at about 150, 200 bucks but professional ones are much more expensive, duh

>>26188316
>So the point of a plotter is basically to make single color stickers?
Yeah, basically. For example you design a sticker that consists of a slogan on a transparent background.
Example: You design a graphics file that says "OP is a fag" written in Olde English font.
The plotter now cuts out these words in olde english font out of the vinyl so you get a single color sticker that says "OP is a fag" without background (so its isolated). Basically it does the same as your hand that's holding a knife - just faster and more accurate.

>>26188071
>How are EVs supposed to stop climate change when they actually produce more greenhouse gases than normal cars?
They don't emit more, but they also won't eliminate climate change by themselves. Everything ultimately must be done.
Cars are simply one of the first on the agenda because they have a relatively short service life, the tun-around time to designing them is shorter, the technology to achieve 100% replacement with BEVs, PHEVs, and FCEVs already exists, and countries have jurisdiction over new cars sold in their territory.
Unlike for instance ships where the technology exists but ships often fly a flag of convenience and aren't subject to local laws, or Airplanes where hydrogen and battery based aircraft are still in early development.

The phase out of internal combustion engine cars as daily use vehicles, and fossil fuel power over the next 30 years, in favor of clean nuclear power and vehicles run from that will eliminate about 20GT of annual emissions. This includes secondary effects of eliminating fossil fuel use like a 1/3 reduction in the amount of oceanic shipping, and reductions in fugitive emissions from fossil fuel extraction.
That's not all emissions, but it is a significant amount.

Even if batteries did only last 5 years before they needed to be recycled, the production cost of the battery in emissions is significantly less than the production cost of a whole car, and right now with only 27% of the US grid being clean baseload energy the pay back period for a whole 100kWh car is less than 2 years. In a few decades when nuclear power is more than 40% of the grid that payback period will be even shorter.
Especially when you consider that in fact current generation EV batteries last 20+ years in their automotive phase, and then a decade or more longer in home storage applications.

I was thinking the purge valve because if the purge valve is stuck open and the gas he's putting in the tank is pushing all the vapor through the valve into the intake he'd have to crank it for a while to get rid of all the fuel vapor enough to get the thing to have the right air fuel ratio to start. the only explanation i could think of for the fuel smell is that the pressurized vapor is making its way towards atmosphere out of the manifold and throttle body into the air outside.
another reason i think it may be the purge valve is that the scan tool was reading 0% purge valve operation at idle, but the commanded purge valve operation fluctuated between 0 and 16% at idle, which tells me the valve is not doing what the ecu wants it to do. (im assuming if this theory is correct that 0% must mean fully open?). also, when we used the scan tool to manually open and shut the vent valve, when we forced the vent valve to the "on" position the engine would stumble and almost stall out for a second. but im not sure if "on" = open or closed. thoughts?

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26182911
0% must mean close… from an armchair mechanic. I don’t think it’s going to open a ton at idle because the low rpm engine won’t be able to burn all that vapor,

On sounds open and you made it too rich. The purge valves get leaky, try to pull a vacuum with the engine off and see if it holds. If it’s leaky, you’re probably getting way more vapor in there than you should, hence the problem starting until you clear some of that vapor out.

A numbers-matching Miata is like a virgin stripper, you can joke about it and smile, but you know full well that it's a lie and she's been inside-out more times than you've had a hot breakfast in your life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185675
Depends which one, there have been a lot of different 6.0L Vortecs in the last 20 years.
Fact is they're all LS-based V8s.
The current 6.2L you'd be looking at would be an L87 6.2L "EcoTec3" Generation V LT1-based LS V8 and you can put all that in whatever order you'd like. L87 is the important bit.
They're fuckin' great motors, "most" LS engines are.

The biggest complaint with GMs newer V8s like this are AFM and DFM.
Active Fuel Management in the earlier L86, and now Dynamic Fuel Management in the current L87.
AFM was pretty shit, and though the stories of unreliability tend to be overblown, the severity of the issues that people did encounter were worth worrying about for a lot of people.
Deleting it is well worth it for a lot of people, it's peace of mind.
DFM is very different, but accomplishes a similar task, just in a much more "clever" way that gives some impressive capabilities.
It is extremely effective, and makes a much bigger difference to both highway and city gas mileage than AFM ever could. It's still quite new, but in my opinion it's far less problematic than AFM, though plenty of people would disagree with me on that.
It's also still possible to disable/delete DFM if someone feels they'd rather go without it.

Those 10-speed trannies are neat, but how "good" they really are in the long term might be hard to say.
As they are, they do work well, and apparently they're quite strong right from the factory, but they're very new still.
It's a Ford/GM joint venture, each gets their own version of each transmission to play with.
Ford designed the 10-speed, GM designed a 9-speed transverse, then they each get to build and use 'em as desired.
The Ford 10R60 10R80 10R140 and GM 10L80 10L90 10L1000, it's all Ford's 10-speed design.
Ford started using it in '17 or '18, but it didn't really become widespread until 2020.
As far as I'm concerned, jury is still out as to how good it'll be in the long-term.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26175302
I have a newer 5th gen, have had it for 4 years now. Drove it multiple times on long 1500+ mile road trips and have gone in snow and rock crawled around the Southwest. It's a good reliable adventure vehicle, one that's reliable simply because it's a relic with tech from 2001-2005ish, despite being sold new today. It's probably the most analog car you can buy new off the dealer lot today if that's your thing. It's been supremely reliable, despite guzzling fuel at a rate of 18-19 mpg on average.

Other than that, this car has some severe drawbacks. It absolutely guzzles fuel, the ride is okay but not cushy or luxurious by any means, the stock new tires were absolute garbage and I went through several changes before settling on a Michelin Defender LTX's as an overall highway and offroad/snow ready tire. It has lots of road and wind noise on long highway trips but holy fuck that roll-down window makes beautiful days that much more enjoyable to drive in. I have the model with the KDSS which is night and day compared to models without it when handling turns, I'm very glad I got it.

When I bought my TRDOR it was $38k OTD, but for the prices they're charging nowadays for such an outdated platform and drivetrain, it is questionable. Knowing the next gen 4Runner has a high chance of being made in Mexico and being turbocharged, I'll probably keep this for an extended time and hope it appreciates in the future or keep it forever as parts will probably be plentiful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26182205

they are still all the rage in any sort of high speed dezert application as they are much stronger than bj's. quality ones will last a while, but they are more expensive than balljoints. for reference, i had a 96 tacoma 2wd pulling 16 " on the front end with upper and lower uniball. i did dezert trips 3-5 times a year, and did not change any of the 4 uniballs for a 8 year period. before i sold the truck, i inspected the front end, and when jacked up there was no play in the uniballs on either upper or lower control arms. they squeaked like a mother fucker though, and since the truck was gutted and caged to the frame it was super annoying. but hey, race truck parts make race truck noises.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183238

The 3vze has an inherently troubled design on the waterjackets on cylinders 1 and 6. The gasket usually does there. If you have to have the HG redone, there are updated gaskets that Toyota created that are better than the originals that were used after the original original asbestos gaskets were banned. Don't cheap out on any parts on this engine. No felpro. No bosch. Toyota OEM, Aisin, Denso only. Go ahead and change the o2 sensor right away. Use Denso. The crossover pipe dumps all the heat from the the passenger side cylinders into # 6. Headers are a good way to eliminate this problem, but they are stupid expensive. Do not use any coolant besides Toyota red coolant.

The engine itself is underpowered. Regearing is the best investment. Power is between 3500 - 4500 rpm which is weird. It bogs at lower rpms. Mine has intake, headers, exhaust, and it's still slow because you just can't get enough air flowing in the engine. SOHC, and tiny valves. What it is, is reliable, and fun as fuck in 4 low. 10-15 k is crazy. I paid 8500 for mine with a fuck ton of upgrades, but that is in the US. I then immediately turned around and replaced the water pump and injectors along with a bunch of other stuff. These things are old man. Hope you can wrench.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26176691
Model T wasn't the first gas car. Before the Model T which opened up car ownership to the middle class of the era, cars had been an expensive impractical novelty for the upper class for about 20 years. Even once the Model T arrived there really wasn't infrastructure to support it, so Ford sold people the ability to make fuel for it at home so they could drive around, even if it was just in their local area. It took a while longer for the prices to really come down, and for the infrastructure to be at a point where car ownership wasn't just something for well to do early adopters interested in new technology.

Tesla Roadster, the first modern EV, which like those first gas cars was an expensive novelty of the upper class, was only 14 years ago.
Over that time the price for ~60kWh EVs has come down from $80k to $25k, and that $25k car is a lot more practical vehicle for about the same inflation adjusted price as the first Model T.
Also remember, by modern standards the Model T wouldn't be a car with its 45mph top speed. It would be a UTV, and there are comparable cheap electric UTVs already on the market.

>>26176858
>So you finally admit it's more like a hybrid than a BEV.
I'm not sure why you think this is a 'gotcha'. Hybrid Electric Vehicles, especially Plug In Hybrid Electric Vehicles are Electric Vehicles. Nobody gets caught up on the 'purity' of the powertrain, especially when talking about powertrain development to conform to the reality of racing rulebooks which allow hydrogen refueling but not battery swapping. One of the advantages of electric powertrains is their ability to take advantage of multiple sources of electricity, and an endurance racing EV using a swappable high capacity battery would still have a similar design with a buffer battery for peak performance, and the KERS.

>will last for less than half an hour at the average power consumption of 120 kW (that's 160 horsepower), leaving you with fuel-cell's 85 kW (114 hp)
Except that's not how it works. The 85kW fuel cell is continually generating electricity, so any time the car is drawing more power than that the fuel cell can provide its drawing on the power stored in the buffer battery, and any time the car is drawing less power than that, the fuel cell is filling the buffer battery back up. Also any time the car is decelerating its using the KERS to put energy back into the buffer battery.
As I said, this is very similar to how endurance racing performance hybrids work, and why they're so dominant because the battery acts as a buffer to keep the generator in a lower stress state.

Considering how much higher performance the N Vision 74's motors are, and how much better the Kinetic Energy Recovery they can provide is compared to the Prius, it would still almost certainly be able to outpace it. Even the new sportier Prius.
Keep in mind the Hyundai car we're talking about isn't a racing optimized vehicle built to be lightweight, its a retro luxury concept show car for this powertrain.
If Hyundai do decide to take this powertrain to LeMans it will almost certainly be in a prototype shell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26177373
>Electric motors in transmissionless vehicles
There are no "transmissionless" vehicles. They have fixed gear transmissions. This works for electric motors because their torque band is so wide. Enough to manage the whole range of normal speeds a typical vehicle will be driven. Which is why the only vehicles that need specially designed motors with varied windings or multiple transmissions are ones with top speeds over about 140mph.

>it's a hybrid electric vehicle
Its not because Fuel Cells are a fully electric powertrain element. Hybrids are hybrids because there are two separate dissimilar powertrains.
Every Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle must have a hydrogen tank, fuel cell stack, battery, and an electric motor. The fuel cell provides a constant electrical current, the battery takes that current and buffers it to provide peak power on demand and handles kinetic energy recovery from the electric motor.
The only difference with the Hyundai concept compared to the Toyota Mirai FCEV is that the buffer battery is much larger, 60kWh vs 8kWh, giving it the ability to drive in a full battery electric mode without needing to use hydrogen in daily use.
Which is a big deal when hydrogen costs the equivalent of $15 a gallon.

Your nitpicks are based on your ignorance of the technology. My post comparing EVs to ICE was in terms of the limitations in stored energy currently.
That is the one advantage internal combustion has right now. The ability to easily store 1MWh in an endurance racing fuel tank, and get another 1MWh relatively quickly.
BEVs typically have less than 100kWh, one tenth the stored energy, and lack the equivalent of an endurance racing fuel tank.
This is the reason why Fuel Cell Range Extending technology is in the process of being approved for endurance racing.
It allows for fully electric vehicles with comparable range and refueling times.

>>26179964
Its not entirely useless. At the very least It explains why some numbers like 34, 68, 100, or 200kWh get thrown around a lot for EVs, as that is 1, 2, 3, and 6 gallon equivalents.
Also why EVs have limited range, and why they're so dependent on efficiency. Most gas cars with 400 or 500 kWh fuel tanks won't even notice the difference between 1000 Wh/mi (30mpg) and 1700 Wh/mi (20mpg), but for an EV with only the equivalent of 2 or 3 gallons of gas its going to really get hurt on range if they only achieve 333 Wh/mi (100mpge) vs the usual 250 Wh/mi (135mpge) especially when charging infrastructure isn't nearly as common as gas infrastructure.

So for instance in the discussion about track use a 20% efficient gas car with a 30 gallon extended range endurance fuel tank has about 1MWh of stored energy, and gets about 200kWh of useful work out of it.
Which is why Porsche, BMW, Tesla and other EV companies are talking about 200kWh as their target for the next-generation of performance EVs.
Or why 12kg hydrogen tanks are getting talked about because with 400kWh of stored energy and 50% efficient fuel cells they also result in about 200kWh of output.

That was true 15 years ago when modern EVs with more than a gallon equivalent were new.
Today, practical short-range daily use EVs can be had for well under $10k, and PHEVs which combine the advantages of those short-range EVs with a car that can still handle 100% of trips with can be had under $30k, half that for used.
Even many long range EVs can be easily obtained by anyone who is middle class for under 60k. Not quite mainstream yet, but any enthusiast who is interested in having an EV can likely swing getting one.

That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

2013 Ninja 650. Started installing my Chinese fairings from eBay this evening. I stopped once I had transferred all the foam inserts from the old ones to the new fairings. Old plastic was scratched up from drops the previous owner had.

New ones are pretty nice. Got them in matte black. They fit 100% perfectly. I am waiting to finish installing them once I pull the exhaust this weekend and paint it with matte black high temp paint. I want to do the gas tank as well in matte black, but that might happen later on. Stock color was a metallic black. New fairings don't have any decals, so it's going to look pretty stealth, save for the yellow rear spring on the shock.

Had to reuse some of the clips that have threads in them, because the clips that came with the fasteners in the new kit didn't clip on right and seat far enough to get the bolts through for proper mounting. Need to grab some new velcro for the tank shroud as well. Got new grips and brake/clutch levers, so those will go on once I get everything else done. Put new mirrors on it as well, since it was missing one when I bought the bike, and the other had fall damage. Cheap bike with 11k on the odo, and about $600 in parts, including new chain, fairings, mirrors, and grips and levers. Total money in project is now ~$3600. I already rode it 500 miles or so since I bought it, but now it's sitting while I do the installs.

PTSD awareness edition, please don't trigger anyone

>For Classics made from 1980 or older, although exceptions are made for cars with a body style that started after 1980

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26170157
1. get it running and drive it as-is
Or are you asking how to get it running?
That's a lot more than 5 things

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26170157
>>26170204
1. inspect oil level and check for water in oil
1a. if there's water you're fucked
2. find out if the engine turns by hand.
2a. if it doesn't, do 3 and 4 then come back in a day or two
3. remove and inspect spark plugs
4. put oil in plug holes
5. (re)install all but 1 plug
6. install battery
6a. watch for big spark when connecting battery
6b. look/listen/smell for burning when connecting battery
7. spin engine via starter motor
7a. listen to how engine is spinning (clunks, rattles, lunging)
7b. check oil pressure while cranking if possible
8. pull a spark plug and check spark
9. there won't be any spark
10. remove distributor cap and rotor
11. file points until you get spark back
12. reassemble rotor, cap, and put plug back
13. disconnect fuel line
14. bottle feed some gas down the carb
15. now it'll fire
16. feed some more gas into the float bowl
17. see if it'll idle
17a. if it doesn't, rebuild carb
18. plumb in alternate fuel tank
19. if it idles, make sure there's water in the radiator
19a. if there isn't, put water in and see where it leaks
19b. fix leaks
20. air up/replace tires
21. drive.

>>26170157
1. Clean it out, inspect status of rust deterioration.
2. Inspect for what's missing, is it complete
3. See if the steering and wheels turn, if it can be pushed around
4. Is the engine locked up? Does it spin freely? Check status of all fluids.
5. Disconnect fuel system, see if it'll fire off with starting fluid if all the above is good.
6. If it won't fire, start diagnosing ignition/electrical/spark system. Then you get into the nitty gritty of parts replacement/rebuilding

First thing I would do is probably put it on a lift and inspect damages, rust and etc.

Then pull out the engine and gearbox, along with anything else that's loose and can be replaced.

Best way to start with abandoned vehicles is to tear everything apart and inspect everything. At least if you're planning on driving it regurarily.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com: Hey fellas. This is a hard post. The Edsel pulled a Tesla during a 10 hour roadtrip. Total loss. I hit a big chunk of something that a truck in front of me kicked up. Rear tire blew out explosively and ripped the gas line off the tank that's beside it. Managed to correct the slide from the blowout and pulled over, but the sparks from the rim lit the open gas line. Nothing I could have done. Dragged my dog and cat out of the burning car, saved some gear, and sat back to watch all that hard work go up in flames. I'm fucking devastated. I'm prepared for the ridicule, but I figured I'd let the thread know that there won't be anymore edselposting, kek.

posts.name: 61 lincoln guy
posts.com:
>>26173884
god damn. worst case scenario, brutal.
why was a cat in ur car?

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26173889
Roadtripping home for the holidays. I was going to spend the entire week down south with the family. I took both my pets so I didn't have to get anyone to watch them while I was gone. The cat was in a carrier, so it made it easy to throw her out of the car.
Fire extinguisher I had in the car was not nearly enough to put out 10+ gallons of gas on fire. It killed it for a few seconds, but it flared right back up. When I knew it was a loss, I just started pulling everything out that I could. I know cars can be replaced, but it doesn't make it sting any less. Literally any other type of fire scenario, I could have handled, but the exploded tire sheared off the line connection at the tank and gas was everywhere. Those were brand fucking new Cokers too, it's not like they were old tires that were ready to blow. I'm pretty crushed.

We almost had a fire when were going out to test the new electric fan installed on a modelA. Fired it up and the glass fuel filter installed along the frame rail shattered from vibration. I had run those on a few different vehicles and never had a problem. If you are running one I would replace it with a disposable. It was spraying fuel right next to the exhaust and would have been a catastrophic disaster. It was still leaking when the engine was shut off because the tank is higher than the pump and line up front. Got to remember to get some bigger fire extinguishers and keep them in all cars and shop. I know of a few guys that lost some really nice builds because of a fuel leak or electrical fire. Insurance fight for one guy was bad, even though he had agreed value coverage, they tried to depreciate the 1932 truck because he didn’t provide a YEARLY appraisal. The guy’s argument was “ how much do you think a 1932 ford truck depreciates in 8 years????” I think he came to an agreement and bought the truck back. Camaro dude, don’t know it your later model second generation has them, but my 72 and 73 Camaros had two pieces of fuel line that connected the hard lines at the front subframe rail. They are only a few inches long but are kind of out of sight and don’t usually get maintained and changed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26179184
The short version is that the oiling system prioritize the crank.

The long version is the oil is pumped up from the oil filter on the left front, then diagonally across the front to the right lifter gallery, then down that gallery towards the rear of the block, across the rear of the engine (which is where the oil pressure sender is) then up the left side gallery. The crank is oiled by channels drilled up to the lifter gallery and crossovers depending on main bearing position. This allows a significant amount of pressure and volume loss around the lifters which is exasperated by wear resulting from the side-thrust loads of the angled pushrods. The fix is a lifter bore bushing kit that's now easily available and can be installed at home where it used to take a machine shop and custom bushings to fix.

posts.com:
Oh, and the other Cleveland issue is the "Chinese lantern" cylinder walls.

The design was a thin-wall casting to begin with and apparently there was significant core shift during casting that took cylinder wall thickness down to the minimum for performance in several areas. Add in losses over the last 50 years and it's now difficult to find a Cleveland block in good enough condition for a Sunday drive let alone big power which is how Clevors came about.

>>26180091
The M is built off the 400 block which has a 10.2(17?) deck height while the C has a 9.2 inch deck (the W is 9.5 fwiw). The 400 main bearing diameter is 3 inches where the C is 2.75. Most 400's have the 429/460 bellhousing pattern while the C has the small block pattern. There is small amount of 400's that had the small block pattern. This number was so small they were considered to be myths for decades.

posts.name: Dracula
posts.com:
>>26180424
It's that if you follow the shop manual you'll get 5 reverse gears and 1 forward. They sourced the transmission from the Renault Alpine and mounted it 180 and swapped a gear so that it has 5 reverse and 1 forward gear. When they copied the service procedure, they omitted the gear swap since Renault didn't have it in their manual and published all the factory service literature incorrectly. This never got fixed since DMC went under and most transmissions never needed a rebuild until the '90s.

The Packard is RUNNING. It's running rich as fuck and a little warm, but I took it to work today and it only ran out of gas once.

Some thoughts:

>The car gets hot in traffic. Dunno if it's because that's just what old cars do, or if it's something else. There's definitely oil in the coolant though, because

>The head was only torqued to about 32 ft-lbs, when spec is 63. I torqued the head, and the breather tube stopped spitting fumes and the car stopped burning oil. Funny that, started holding temperature longer too

>The car had no thermostat in it, due to aforementioned overheating, which was primarily caused by

>The car had a bad radiator cap, which is why the car never truly *overheated,* it got to boiling and sat there. I replaced the cap, and the car almost immediately started holding temperature.
> The fuel tank is full of rust, and the hard line is covered in rust and small holes. I put a 12 gallon tank in the trunk, ran a line and power back, and installed a 6v fuel pump. No issues now.

>The car rides like a fucking cloud, but it bumpsteers to a hilarious degree. Never driven a car that fights me so hard before.

>The carb is running rich as FUCK, and every single gasket on it is oozing fuel. Needs a rebuild and a tune-up.

>Car has minor lifter noise, but it could be the mechanical fuel pump. Dunno yet

Having driven one of them, they aren't supposed to get that hot. Your head gasket is likely going bad or was compromised by the low torque. You also need to flush the block and radiator with CLR and water while there's no thermostat. Those passages are corroded and the water distribution tube may be compromised and is likely the source of it running hot. I believe there are stainless repros made.

Clean that up and flush the radiator and block and it should run cool. Those I8s can displace a LOT of heat.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26183097
CFM flow numbers will let you know almost the exact horsepower the motor will make, assuming you run a good exhaust and intake and carb or otherwise choke it.
Intake CFM x .26= theoretical horsepower x percent exhaust flow.
Example: 325x.26= 84.5 hp per cylinder
84.5 x 8= 676. Times 8 for 8 cylinders
Say your head flow 85% of what the intake flow on the exhaust side.
676x .85= 574.6 HP.
This is why good heads are important if you want to make power. It’s also why head ported that can produce flow numbers can make a very good living. That’s also why SBC race heads have 2.05” or 2.08” intake valves.
Edelbrock makes good stuff, but it is expensive. They tend to put packages together and advertise their package horsepower. They make ok power but never the power that a ported AFR, Brodix, Trick Flow, or others make. For one reason is their port cc size is usually on the smaller side like 180 or 295cc when the others make monster ports of 220-240cc. A 240cc Small block would make great peak power but wouldn’t drive well on the street. I once got to port on a set of new Brodix heads, asked the owner what they were going on and he replied “Earnhardt’s car” He had me hog them way out, I was afraid to fuck up an over $1,000 bare casting.

>Planned on taking it to a nearby Lexus dealership
Let me tell you how this is going to go down.

You’re going to take it there, for $250 they will inspect it and then bring you an itemized list of issues that need to be fixed with a total cost of $15,000, then there will be a question in there about the coolant that may be internal to the engine and show the cost of an engine replacement bringing the total Bill, if issue found, to $22,000.

100% a waste of your time. That GX has been wrecked if you see screws where there should be pushpins. I am capable of doing 95% of vehicle maintenance and that wouldn’t scare me.... at $4-5k, maybe $7k if I personally inspected max. Lastly, mismatched tires on an AWD vehicle is a huge no-no, you absolutely cannot have two tires with different tread wear on an AWD vehicle. Spending real money on that specific vehicle is retarded. Unless the GX market absolutely went fucked in the past 12 months GX of that age should be found if you widen your scope for $8-11k in better condition than that.

Go find a low mileage 3.7/5.3 H3 if you want another decent off-road option to look into.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26188708
Part of getting the experience is just getting your hands dirty even if you don't entirely know what you're doing and then learning from your mistakes.

Some tips from my own limited personal experiences:
>Buy a Haynes manual for your vehicle
>Watch a couple youtube videos of people fixing the same part on the same car as you are attempting to fix
>Expect the job to take twice as long as you originally planned
>budget a little extra money for parts or tools you might have forgotten
>always use the right tool for the job, don't niggerrig things
>take lots and lots of pictures of how your car used to look before you started ripping it apart
>don't be a dumbass, wear gloves and goggles
>shop towels and miscellaneous containers are your best friends, have lots on hand

You're right, when SHTF and the computer shits the bed, I'd rater be diagnosing a bad throw arm on a dual weighted dizzy than tracking wiring shorts in a loom of 300 wires.

>>26183223
Not him, pre-war anon here again. Sorry for filling the bait thread. I did some time on an (admittedly somewhat unorthadox) racing team a couple summers ago. Like >>26183077 said, racing teams are largely volunteer work. If you're serious about wanting to join one, IMO the best way to get on one is to go to larger racing events and just get your name out as much as possible. Stop in at tents and ask if they need help with dumb menial shit. Shoot the shit with the guys about the car. This is assuming you sort of know your way around cars already and are not a total sperg. Most will say no, but occasionally, you'll be in the right place at the right time and you can jam your foot in the door. I know a couple of buddies who got on teams doing stuff like that and they had a blast all summer. Again though, they're making pretty much no money.

If you want to make money around race cars, then you have to talk to the track prep guys. Depending on company size and clients, you can actually make a pretty good bit of cash doing track support. But, you better be fucking excellent at making stuff work in a pinch, wrenching quickly and effectively, and make very few mistakes under pressure. It's legitimately a pretty tough job, even at the more amateur level races. Definitely something you have to work your way up to IMO, but those jobs are out there.

>>26185176
Few very important points:

1) PCs, drones, and RC cars don't require specialized tools or heavy lifting and they can all be worked on at a coffee table if you want usually with a $10-$20 tool kit. Also, most do it out of necessity because there aren't many places that even offer repair/building services for drones and RC cars and most PC shops are more geared towards fixing pre-built computers than customizing one. If you get stuck and can't finish, you won't have an HOA screeching at you for having a partially disassembled car in sight of the public or not be able to get to work/school/grocery store/etc. and have spend hundreds towing it to a repair shop.

2) There are tons of PC gaming enthusiasts that don't build their own computers or have any desire to. They either buy prebuilts or pay a company to put their computer together and for most I don't blame them. I've seen what a shit show a lot of first time builders do to their computers and they're better off having someone experienced do it. I have the knowledge to build a PC, but every time I consider it I end up finding a prebuilt on sale that has the same or better parts for less and end up getting that instead. Like the car, I get no enjoyment or satisfaction of putting it together, I only do it if it's overwhelmingly less expensive or convenient (i.e. I'm not driving to a computer shop to have them swap a graphics card, LOL). In fact, the biggest thing keeping me from upgrading my 1070 to a 3080 right now is because I'd also need to upgrade the power supply and I really don't want to have to unplug dozens of ports and dig the computer out (almost every port is used and it's behind my FFB steering wheel setup and other stuff), have to re-reroute all of the cables for a new power supply, hope neither the new power supply or used 3080 have issues, and have to put it all back all to find out the 3080 might be bottlenecked by the rest of the computer.

Interior is holding up well, no delamination/bolster wear/squeaks/cracks/etc (visor mirror cover broken).
>track rat
does he use r-compounds? local track use oval bankings? basically is it driven fast enough or in a way to oil starve or overwhelm the AOS.
Cracked heads/water pump failures. blades break off, temp sensor is slow, ....
Just drop the oilpan and look at the bottom of the bores before purchase. That ensures no bore scoring (via the plugs is worthless) and you can check for debris in the oil. look for signs of non-oem hoses/clamps/etc. can be done in the driveway with some blocks of wood and <1hr.

~$15-20k seems reasonable with a $15k+ engine rebuild looming over your head.

$7k seems like the floor for auctions with a blown motor. rare'ish red one w/ a blown motor + 136k miles on BAT currently @ $5,500: https://bringatrailer.com/listing/2000-porsche-911-carrera-coupe/
With 996/997 GT3s over $100k now, GT3 swapping base 911 shells is getting more common it will at least be worth some coin when it blows up.

>I really don’t buy high Mile cars so im looking for advice. Spin a bearing?

That's 210k miles of the chassis/body flexing everywhere it's been driven. Metal weakens over time and it is a much less rigid car than it was when it was new. If it's a track car that flexing has been happening to the extreme, to say nothing of the engine and transmission. One track day can put more wear on a car than years of daily driving. The pistons don't move in a purely straight line so a high-mile engine will have bores that are possibly out of round and/or scored meaning lower compression and an extremely high potential for a very expensive rebuild in the very near future. Then there's the plastic parts which tend to be a little biodegradable

>>26187184
>GT3 AOS separator
nice
>>26187739
>dry sump
Doesn't scavenge from the pan to an external tank - normal pickup tube. But it does have cam-driven scavenge pumps that return oil from the head. That's where the problems begin.

GT3 vs M96 scavenge pump comparison: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X7Lxrj6yYro

>>26188027
>mods he did to the oil pan
traditionally oiling issue are getting air in the pickup tube, losing oil pressure, and spinning a bearing - thats NOT the case here,
Under 'heavy g braking + left turn' oil gets held in the front of the passenger side head and won't drain back. The head casting slopes to a common pump inlet vs the GT3/Turbo that uses pickup points in each corner to a 2 inlet pump. There was a 'fix' (X51) that basically adds an external drain line and upgrades to a '2 inlet' pump but wasn't used in the 996.2.
The 997 further improved w/ a different design vacuum pump and the 991/992 went back to 4 instead of 2 scavenge pumps.

That said, there are some people who see oil pressure drops on r-compounds because of the pickup placement - this seems to fix it: https://rennlist.com/forums/996-forum/1260027-ultimate-integrated-dry-sump-uids-v2-2-a.html
deeper pans may lower oil temps, but increase risk of damage and don't seem to solve pickup.
[/oil pump autism]
>>26187195
>chain guide / oil cooler cost
no clue. hopefully PorscheTechAnon will chime in.
I don't know the secrets of what requires dropping the engine removed vs lowered in place. I think you can do the oil cooler and camshaft chain guides in the car. The timing chain guide cover probably requires a lot of shit to be taken off and outside the car. This madlad did 300K+mi on stock tensioners (only replaced one because of the actuator): https://www.6speedonline.com/forums/996/342783-996-vario-pads-82k-2.html#post4815093 But if the plastic guide fails, the chain could skip a few degrees

in car oil cooler replacement: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCBqXiR9kys

>>26187860
It was a nothing package people bought for the name.
Generally the "American Edition" meant you got the wood trim, tan leather seats, gold badges, and gold BBS rims, all of which were available separately as options or in other packages.

It was intended, and this isn't a joke, to attract old people.
It's basically the "chinkanese knock-off Cadillac" package, a collection of their most superficial and tacky options.

Nissan has bungled its exit from the FIA World Endurance championship as badly as it handled competing in the fiercely competitive sports cars series.

Approximately 40 employees at the Indianapolis-based LMP1 program were notified by e-mail the program had been cancelled Tuesday morning, yet with many of the staffers on vacation for the holidays and away from work e-mail, news of the firing, for some, came from a press release the Japanese brand decided to post in its global newsroom. Those who did turn up for work Tuesday morning were barred access to the building, and senior team officials, who were also caught by surprise, stepped in to call and inform (or confirm) the sudden dismissals for all who worked at the facility.

Nissan's cancelation of the troubled program, just days before Christmas, is the latest chapter in what has been a truly tumultuous journey from concept to race.

Road & Track was present for the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO's debut on Dec. 19, 2014, at Circuit of The Americas, where the radical, front-engine, front-wheel-drive prototype suffered through a troubled introduction that made only modest gains over the next 368 days until the program's termination. https://www.roadandtrack.com/motorsports/news/a27710/nissan-fired-its-lmp1-employees-over-e-mail/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26075559
Pretty much..
“Behind the engine and beneath the cockpit is a kinetic energy recovery system using two flywheels developed by Torotrak. The flywheels gain energy from the use of the front brakes then discharges that energy back to the front wheels via a driveshaft running over the top of the combustion engine. The flywheels can also output power to a secondary driveshaft which is connected to a limited-slip differential at the rear of the car which feeds epicyclic gearboxes located in each rear wheel hub, allowing the GT-R to be all-wheel drive if necessary.”

Sound complicated? It should, because it is.

Additionally, while the engine is in front of the driver, it’s also behind the centerline of the front wheels, so it’s more of a front-mid layout. As Bowlby explained in an interview with Racecar Engineering:

“The front tyres on the Nissan GT-R LM NISMO are bigger than the rear tyres – 14 inch wide front vs. 9 inch rear. This is due to the way that mass is distributed in the car. We have moved the weight bias forwards to give us traction for the front-engined, front-wheel drive. We’ve also moved the aero forwards so we’ve moved the capacity of the tyres forward to match the weight distribution. So the aero centre of pressure, the mass centre of gravity and the tyre capacity are all in harmony and that means we have bigger tyres at the front than the rear”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26068883
Mitsubishi Motors completely abandoned RWD cars with the exception of the Starion in the 1980s. This would be one of the many decisions that would bleed the brand over the next few decades.
When the big three of Japan decided to come out with their bespoke luxury brands, Mitsubishi decided there was no need for this despite having basically no clout in the American market, they made fleet and commuter vehicles. This combined with the pathetic 3.0 V6 meant the gussies up Galant known as the Sigma was a failure.
They also gradually fucked up their sports car lineup in the states as well. The DSM cars, Chrysler's FWD sports cars, and the captive import Starion (Chrysler Conquest), occupied slightly varying price levels but were essentially in competition with each other in the same showrooms.
The GTO/3000GT used a twin-turbo version of the 6G72 3.0 V6 in the highest trims. We know now that even this engine struggled to power the AWD system of the over 3500 lb car which wasn't helped by the two turbochargers. What's stranger is that the 6G74 3.5 V6 was dropped in multiple Mitsubishi vehicles, SUVs and sedans, and was able to approach the twin-turbo 6G72 in power in NA form.
During the height of the Fast and Furious tuner hype, Mitsubishi cut corners and made the third generation Eclipse FWD only, but let you have a V6.
The company would spend the 2000s and 2010s producing shitty commuter cars for the states, the market they invested so much into entering through the Chrysler partnership. By the 2010s they were essentially a second class Jap brand like Suzuki and Isuzu.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185351
>You can use just the electric motors on a prius?
Yes, EV only up to 25 mph. But it will also shut the engine off and go EV only any time the power load is low. That's what the "Power bar" display tells you when you use any Toyota hybrid. Anything halfway below half the ecozone will make them run in EV mode.
It can run in EV mode up to 86 mph.
So, you can indeed have the engine shut off while going down the highway, assuming the load is low enough.
Great for off-ramps. Shuts off right when you get off, and can charge up the whole way to the stop light, won't even use the brakes, just regen into the battery.
>pic related.

>>26185971
3rd gen was pretty quiet.
4th gen will stay under 2k rpm pretty much all the time. Even highway merging, it won't go above 3k rpm.
They are a bit buzzy, but they only make 96hp.
In normal daily driving, it will be around 0-1500 rpm.
They "idle" at 1200.
Because if they're running, they're charging.
They sometimes will charge when parked.
The engine pops on, goes right to 1200 and 80% load, and just rumbles for a minute, then shuts off.
Overall, neat and reliable things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26184683
V6 Challengers, especially the late model with the zf8.
They get a bad rap specifically for being mass market fleet cars and the Challenger platform as a whole has an unfair reputation as a poor handler. They tend to come from the factory a little under-equipped (thin tires and open diffs) while even the base GM and Ford offerings are generally ready to rock. With a few mods on the Chally the playing field evens significantly.
The truth is they are extremely well engineered where it counts, durable, and are equally at home in straight lines or corners. The freighttrain-like cornering stability is wild and you can really bring the car up to the edge of traction easily. It drives like a much lighter, smaller car than it is. With a few simple mods they are unstoppable. Wrenchlets may decry the Pentastar, but it's easily one of the best engines of all time and sounds great with a custom exhaust.
It's smooth and quiet until you don't want to be.
Also, engine bay cupholders.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26183798
Do not buy an auto. The 3 speed is atrocious and ruins the car IMO. They're fucking awesome cars if you take care of them though. I've done Spec 944 and owned 4. My last shitbox one had 400k miles on the original motor before I sold it, and I never did more than brakes and the timing belt every 40k miles. I drove that thing from Cali to Virginia two times without an issue.
In my experience, post 85.5 are usually more stout reliability wise. I dailyed my last one all year without problems. Good news is that the amount of information out there is unending and parts are plentiful. Clark's Garage will be your friend for wrenching advice. They're fun, cheap shitboxes to chuck around and great for learning to wrench. The prices are only going up, so make your move now if you are going to get your hands on one. Just be wary that you'll have to do your own work and be semi-competent turning a wrench. But retarded 16 year old me was able to keep a $900 shitbox '83 on the road as my daily with $30 of harbor freight tools, I'm sure you'll be able to as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185704
Thanks for the genuine reply anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185743
No problem mate. Don't listen to the NARP fags and the retards that have never even driven one. If you're looking for a relatively balanced, fun drivers car to chuck around, they're great. If you do buy one, spend the cash to buy a good one instead of a shitbox that needs a lot of work. Do the timing belt first and foremost.
>https://www.clarks-garage.com
Has such good step-by-step guides on how to fix literally anything on these cars that even a down syndrome retard could do most of this work. Read through the procedure for the timing belts and see if that's something you think you could do. If you think you can, that's a good metric for knowing if you've got the capability to keep one on the road, mechanic skill wise.
My '83 had problems out the ass and was under the chopping block every weekend, but my '86 as previously mentioned was a tank, as were my other post 85.5 cars. Find a good one and test drive it, see if you like it first, obviously.

Yeah, Clark was an OG. Previously mentioned, my first car when I was 16 was a $900 944, and I managed to stumble through a timing belt job with almost no tools and zero experience thanks to Clark, you'll be fine. The only job that's really a pain on these cars is the clutch, but if you have access to a lift, being a mechanic, it really isn't terribly bad, just shittier than a normal clutch. Read the "buying a 944" page on Clark's site and take a few pointers from there before going to look at one. If you're seriously interested in them, I'd say go for it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Good choice, I have thought about it as well, in the end I didn't go for it but that was due to my lack of budget in the end, not because the car was bad.
I have made my research and they are very fun and reliable (for an older car at least).
There is a bigger Porsche 924/944 scene in german, check their forums with google translate.
I would give you just one advice: Only a buy a 924/944 if the last owner has had it for at least 5-7 years and constantly invested money and effort in making it run flawlessly. It should have a full history and repairs at specialists that are reknown in the 944 community in your country. Not some mediocre chain workshop. So if possible buy it from a Porsche fan, a collector, somebody who loves cars, etc.
If you have a bad feeling or don't trust the guy, don't do it. Check you local forum, you can also aks there whether people are selling their 944. There is a good chance that many of these cars are in good shape and well kept.

>>26184978
Ok here's some actual help.

Learn about tires, and learn that maximizing tire grip in any condition is EVERYTHING for safety and maintaining control of your car.

Things like, understanding that when you turn, your braking and accelerating ability are limited

Also, things like, when you accelerate too much and your tire is shitty, or too small, or the road is slippery, or the car is just too powerful, the wheel is going to spin instead of "hook"

So don't punch the gas when you are in a turn. And don't punch the gas when you are at a lower speed. Powerful cars make use of power at higher speeds. Lower speeds, the car will be so powerful, it will just spin the wheels like crazy, even on amazing tires, on a warm day with good pavement.

From now on, you must learn to "ease" into the gas, and constantly monitor your car for wheelspin through sound & feeling, while keeping your eyes on the road.

Eyes must never come off the road when you drive spiritedly.

You will be able to tell when your car tires let go and start spinning. At that point, you DO NOT hit the brakes, you simply ease off the gas a little bit, and keep looking ahead. If it's a good handling car, it should catch itself, and grip the road again, and you can proceed normally.

Losing control happens in a matter of seconds, fractions of a second, even. So you must tread carefully when doing high-speed turns and maneuvers. Eventually, you will learn the car, and be able to push your own limits a little bit more, til you find the point of the car's own limits where it gets really really dangerous doing something consistently.

So good tires are everything, but paying attention to road conditions, learning the car itself, watching where you are going, and not going too fast to know what's around a corner or where your tires lose grip is also essential to not crashing your shit.

Congrats on the 2SS, I hope you have fun with it. V8s are a dying breed, and it's good to live in its last hurrah.

>>26169944
Just try out a manual car and decide for yourself, if you have any friend who has one. You get more control, it's more direct, it's more fun. You can do it slow, you can do it fast, you can give yourself a little bit of oversteer by changing gear too rough in the corner on purpose, you can give yourself a nice bit of extra turn-in by heel-toeing and putting lower gear for extra engine braking, or you can just go nice and smooth and enjoy your own abilities to do that. Pulling off a nice and smooth rev-match is properly pleasant.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26179264
>>26179321 this is the band aid answer and will work fine until you learn the real way.
Which is:

>get the muscle memory down for how much throttle you need to get the RPMs up to about 2k-4k without looking at the tach.
>be able to do this every time without thinking about it, as fast as possible (half a second or less)
>learn the exact bite point of the clutch and be able to get to it without over or undershooting it

then be stopped on a hill at a red light, lights about to turn green
>right foots holding the brake pedal in
>left foot pushes clutch in, shift to 1st gear from neutral
>right foot still holding in the brake
>light turns green
>right foot lets off the brake fully and immediately moves to the throttle and gets the RPMs up to 2-4k depending on your engine and steepness of the hill
>AT THE SAME EXACT TIME AS THE STEP ABOVE the left foot lets out the clutch to the bite point
>hold it there til the car gets to about a walking pace (less than a second usually), then you should be able to let out the clutch completely
>increase throttle to go with the flow of traffic

thats it. car goes up the hill without backing up or with minimal back up (3-4 inches at most, even if youre on the slower side)

The only sacrifice is the practice you have to put in to be consistent and confident with this every time, but this is probably the only semi hard part about driving manual besides heel-toe downshifting

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185120
Fuel Economy: The Wankel’s combustion chamber is long, thin, and moves with the rotor. This causes a slow fuel burn. Engines try to combat this by using twin (leading and trailing) spark plugs. Even with the two plugs, combustion is often incomplete, leading to raw fuel being dumped out the exhaust port. The small 1.3 liter 232 horsepower two rotor engine in the 2011 Mazda RX-8 gets worse fuel economy (16 city / 23 highway) than the 6.2 liter 455 horsepower V8 engine used in the 2015 Corvette Stingray (17 city / 29 highway).

Emissions: The unburnt fuel, along with burned oil (described below) both result in terrible emissions from Wankel engines. The emissions problems are one of several reasons the RX-8 was pulled from production.

wankel-inside-kart-engineSealing: Rotors use seals on the faces, seals around the central port, and most importantly apex seals. The apex seal rides the wall of the housing, sealing each of the three chambers formed by the rotor. The apex seals are under extreme thermal and pressure stresses as they travel around the engine housing. Failing apex seals are the primary cause of rotary engines going down for overhaul. YouTube is littered with videos showing the rotary overhaul process.

Much like piston rings, these seals have to be lubricated. However, due to the design of the rotary engine, there is no way to keep the oil lubricating the seals out of the combustion chamber.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185139
2 strokes basically have to inject fuel as the cylinder is compressing the air rather than having a dedicated intake stroke like a 4 cycle. If you open a valve the air would be pushed out of the valve rather than entering the engine. Most 2 strokes inject fuel through the crankcase and the vacuum left by the exhaust gasses leaving draws the fuel in through the crankcase. That is why 2 cycle fuel is mixed with oil. Diesel 2 strokes can get around this problem because they inject fuel at TDC which still works in a 2 cycle, but they still require a supercharger or turbo to force air in because of the reasons above.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26187633
Yes. A rotary will always have worse mileage an emissions compared to a piston engine for two main reasons
You cannot get a 100% thorough and clean burn on a rotary
You must inject oil into the combustion chamber to lubricate the apex seals (the rotary equivalent of piston rings)
These are fundamental flaws in the design that cannot be fixed, and the main reason why you'll probably never see them in a production car again

Fine, I guess I'll have to post it again.
From Wikipedia:
"Initial layout and design elements for the 86 were presented by Toyota using its "FT" (Future Toyota) concept car nomenclature. The first was the Toyota FT-HS, which was presented at the North American International Auto Show in 2007. It had a front engine, rear-wheel drive layout and 2+2 seating and was powered by a V6 engine with hybrid electric assistance. In 2008, Toyota bought 16.5% of Fuji Heavy Industries, which includes the Subaru automotive brand.[8] Toyota, led by project leader Tetsuya Tada,[9] then invited Subaru to partner in the project, by co-developing the new D-4S boxer engine.[10] The offer, which conflicted with Subaru's reputation for high performance all-wheel drive (AWD) cars, was rejected. The project came to a six-month halt before Toyota invited journalists and Subaru engineers to test a developmental prototype. Following the test, Subaru agreed to become further involved in development.[11]


Toyota FT-86 Concept (2009)
The collaboration produced a concept car, the FT-86 Concept, which debuted at the Tokyo Motor Show in October 2009. Smaller than the FT-HS, the design of the FT-86 was further refined by Toyota's ED2 design studio while the hybrid V6 powerplant was replaced by the new D-4S boxer. Subaru provided the chassis, modifying it from their Impreza. The custom red paint was based on the backside of a Japanese macaque.[12]

At the 2010 Tokyo Motor Show, Toyota launched its G Sports line of aftermarket accessories, along with the FT-86 G Sports concept car. It featured G Sports carbon fibre panels, a vented bonnet, rear wing, 19 in (48 cm) wheels, Recaro race seats, and an interior rollcage.[13] The D-4S engine also added a turbocharger.[14]

In 2011, Toyota and Subaru unveiled five near-production concept cars to show their progress with the project."

Direct injection is a meme. Injectors are traditionally placed in the intake ports to clean the port walls to increase engine life. Direct injection is a scam that in the long run means you don’t have fuel cleaning your intake every time you drive. That’s why you’ll notice cars with direct injection have intakes caked with black gunk which ultimately reduces power and engine life.

Continue to believe direct injection is necessary though. It’s a scam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26184295
Direct injection allows for fun games with fuel timing and stratification for running leaner and with higher compression (static or forced). One of the big deals for the subaru/toyota collaboration on this project was the use of toyota's scheme for using a mix of both port and direct injection as needed. Hence why this version of the FA engine doesn't suffer from carboned up intake valves like the on the wrx.

>>26183665
Car mechanic here, you got 2 Options:
1) Replace the water with the correct amount of anti freeze. This is also necessary because anti freeze acts as a lubricant for your water pump, prevents rust in iron engine parts and it gives the coolant a much greater heat capacity than pure water.
2) Drain the water immediately before it freezes. Obviously don't start your engine afterwards.

You don't know how fast the water inside your engine will freeze. Do you know what happens then? Ice has a larger volume than liquid water. That means your water channels - everything gets put under so much pressure that even cast iron breaks.

Do you want that? No? Then get some motherfucking anti freeze or drain your entire coolant system ASAP

https://collinsadapters.com/swap-kits/honda/honda-k-series-to-mazda-rx-8-swap-kit.html
$2500 for a swap kit using the RX8 6 speed box. Doesn't include the engine, the ancillaries for the engine, the ECU, the harness. You're looking at 1k to 2k or more for the engine depending on variant and mileage. If you want a Type R motor, you're going to be paying well over 5 grand. A K24A from something American is probably the better option for yanks. 6-9 hundred depending on mileage and condition. A wiring specialities harness for a Honda K series starts at $800. And you'll need to know what you need on the harness in relation to the engine you're putting in.

This. I used to mix my own coolant from concentrate and I had the mix too low. I went for a drive at -30f and found that the whole cooling system grenaded from frozen coolant. Unless you only use the 50/50 mix you should get one of the turkey baster looking testers.

>>26184426
Battery warmers are a meme unless you live in michigan or alaska. You're better off replacing your battery regularly and getting one with decent cold cranking amps. AGM batteries are great for that. I'm partial to optima yellow myself. 2 years old is nothing, but if it was a cheap battery it might have shit CCA. Check the label. 600+ will crank the fuck out of anything smaller than a V8.

Synthetic oil is more useful than an oil pan heater. You'd be surprised how much better it flows at cold temps vs conventional - even with the same viscosity rating. Better flowing oil makes your car easier to start and significantly reduces cold start wear.

If you do deem it necessary to have a supplemental heater, get one of the freeze plug style block heaters that goes into the coolant.

>>26185696
If you can't find fuel injectors, often they are cross-compatible.
I swapped fuel injectors in my 1994 BMW K75 motorcycle for injectors off of a 90s 6cylinder Ford F-150, per forums they had better spray pattern.
You may need to take some measurements of the existing fuel injectors and play around looking on rockauto and such and try to find something that will work. I'd replace all the injectors with the same, though.
Alternatively, you can try cleaning the injector by removing it, opening the injector with some 12v across the leads, and spraying carb cleaner thru it or something like that.

Anyways, bit of a different capability requirement for our standards.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26185896
No matter how hard I try, I can't seem to find a boring motorcycle. They're just fucking great.
Even after 4 years (including a 50km daily commute for the last 9 months) my 250 still puts a smile on my face every time I ride, and makes every day feel like a little adventure.

When you're picking a bike, ask yourself the following questions?
>What interested you about bikes in the first place?
>What will you (truthfully) use it for? e.g. commuting, all-day or multi-day trips, blasting through twisty roads, riding in tight and technical off-road sections.
>What style do you like? e.g. sports bike, cruiser, ADV, scooter, naked, retro, dual-sport.
>Where do you live? The environment of Kansas might have different requirements than Scotland, and your bike might need to adjust.
>Do you have any rational or emotional constraints? e.g. only wanting a bike made in Italy, or being particularly short or tall.

Well that answers questions 1, 3 and 5.
At first impression I can say to buy a Ninja 400 since they're genuinely one of the best bikes (in their class) of all time, but do you have any answers for what you'll use it for or where you live? The reason I ask is because there are ostensibly pretty similar bikes which are slightly tailored for different use cases. Like a CBR500R will perform really similarly to a Ninja 400, but it makes a trade-off of being less sporty (bigger, heavier, lower revving) but more comfortable for long trips. Or if you wanted something much pointier with great performance but at the trade-off of extremely uncomfortable, you could go for the absolute opposite end of the spectrum with an R7.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26185896
Anything (~40hp) 400cc-ish is going to be able to go triple digit speeds and be more than enough power to really do anything legal on the street.

What you should do is make a list of what you're looking for in a bike:
>What style I want Sport/Adv/Dual/Cruiser/Cafe/etc
>What riding position I prefer
>What' I'm using this bike for, daily commute? Highway (+65mph?), off road?, city?, country roads?
Overall any motorcycle is a good motorcycle and don't be upset that you bought a cruiser, but after riding a thousand miles learn that you really wanted a dual sport. That's totally fine because being a new rider you don't even really know what you like.

But seriously, write down all the features that you think you want, and go investigate which bikes match the important parts of your list.
